greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square part of 4th-power-free part of n.
comment: Equivalently, biquadratefree (4th-power-free) part of square part of n.
Multiplicative. The terms are squares of squarefree numbers (A062503).

Every positive integer n is the product of a unique subset S_n of the terms of A050376 (sometimes called Fermi-Dirac primes). a(n) is the product of the members of S_n that are squares of prime numbers (A001248).
link: Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Square part
example: Removing the 4th powers from 192 = 2^6 * 3^1 gives 2^(6 - 4) * 3^1 = 2^2 * 3 = 12. So the 4th-power-free part of 192 is 12. The square part of 12 (largest square dividing 12) is 4. So a(192) = 4.
mathematica: f[p_, e_] := p^(2*Floor[e/2] - 4*Floor[e/4]); a[n_] := Times @@ (f @@@ FactorInteger[n]); Array[a, 100] (* _Amiram Eldar_, Jun 01 2020 *)
xref: A007913, A008833, A008835, A053165 are used in formulas defining the sequence.
The formula section details how the sequence maps the terms of A003961, A331590.
results.author: _Peter Munn_, May 31 2020
